events.target_title: Nautilus crashes on expanding folders
Copy browsing history when opening a new window[Feature Request]

note.body:
>It makes no sense to copy the current directory and not to copy the file history.

Opening a new window and pointing the view to the same location is not the same as cloning the window, and nor does it imply any sort of hierarchical relationship between the windows.

For an example, detaching a tab retains the history, because it is attached to that particular view. Materializing a window out of thin air makes for ambiguities as to what properties it can be expected to have.

We’re getting to a point where we might as well be arguing semantics. What could work is having an action that does what you want, i.e. clones a window, but that would be redundant and terrible from a UX perspective. An alternative is giving a different meaning to “opening a new window at the same location” - “cloning the window”.

events.target_title: Copy browsing history when opening a new window[Feature Request]

note.body:
>You are contradicting yourself if you keep this

I’m not sure if logic alone dictates what features appear in Nautilus, or any other product.

I think that coming up with some hard data (conducting a study or what have you) on users’ expectations or use patterns would be more constructive than butting heads here. Of course, on the other hand, we could do some experimenting, but then we’d need to do the same to measure what difference it made.

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body: I'm open to dropping the `[In]` / `[Out]` naming convention (IIRC it was adopted to avoid namie clashes if you had UCM devices with the same name, but I don't know if that's right).

events.target_title: mixer-control: adding ucm port names for audio device selection

note.body:
After some conversation with Tanu on PulseAudio IRC, some comments:

1. The `[In]` and `[Out]` prefixes are there because UCM Devices can be bidirectional, and contribute 2 ports

2. I think we should have backwards compatible names if possible, so that existing apps and scripts continue to work

3. The mapping should be done on the PulseAudio side, I see two options for this:
   a. Add values in UCM to provide a name override, and use that in PulseAudio -- I don't know if this is useful across audio servers, and might result in repetition
   b. Have the mapping inside the PulseAudio code, which would mean changes are hard to make for users if there are mappings we miss
   c. Have a configuration file that PulseAudio uses to perform this mapping for UCM (imo this is the best case)

events.target_title: Better differentiation of users in the chat backlog

note.body:
Florian Müllner [wrote](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/polari/issues/23#note_7321):
>  Custom color markers

Out of the three you present this does look like the most elegant approach to me too. Might be worth getting an experimental branch up and running to see how this looks like in practice.


Another approach to consider which could solve this issue simultaneously might be implementing avatar support and display avatars in the chatview next to the nicks. Although use of avatars are in the minority right now on IRC (only supported in IRCv3 AFAIK?), we could work on a suitable fallback such as generating colors, patterns or suitable pictures based on IRC nicks as placeholders. That's a much more involved approach though and will require both work on visual design side of things and coding. The visual art direction for the fallback avatars themselves could be something a bit playful, personal, but most importantly something which feels GNOME-y and also is minimalistic though.

events.target_title: Current location fails, unresponsive

note.body: I just realized what the problem is here (I think). It seems you have location services disabled (in Settings). Ideally Maps would show a notification (with a button to open the Settings' privacy panel), but due to a bug with Clutter views embedded in Gtk widgets with other widgets overlayed on them, when using Wayland these notifications will not show up. As a workaround you should be able to enable location services manually first in Settings (Privacy → Location).

Hi @danigm, 

I tried to remove the spacing on the top, and I now figured out the original problem, the user icon  is higher than the Nick Name and the first message, this produce some spacing between the first message (widget) and the rest of the messages of the same user (small_widgets), this confuse a bit the eye because detach the group of messages, or better the spacing between the first message and the others is higher of the spacing that the other messages have between each other.

The possible solutions are:
- Make the user icon smaller (5px smaller should be enough)
- Make all the spacing higher between messages of the same user, and even more higher for messages of different users
- Refactor the message list to have a list of messages widgets that have inside a list of messages from the same user

So let me know what the best way to go from your point of view.

Regards

events.target_title: Safe Browsing support violates Google's new terms of service

note.body: @mcatanzaro, thanks for the heads-up, though I'm not sure at this point how to proceed with Epiphany's API key. As you mentioned, we'd probably have to remove the Safe Browsing support or tweak a clever scheme to make the key secret :thinking:. Nevertheless, Epiphany's API key will still remain in the git history "forever" (unless we force delete those commits) and in the tarballs released over the past year or so. So one might argue that our key is irrevocably compromised. We'd probably have to ask Google to invalidate the current key and request a new one in that case.

Sorry, I don't understand the question. Do you mean whether the extension preferences could get a list of all available applications? The answer to that is [yes](https://developer.gnome.org/gio/stable/GAppInfo.html#g-app-info-get-all), but there's no off-the-shelf widget in GTK+ to display it.

The alternative to writing a custom application list in the extension preferences would be to change GTK+ itself - I've proposed [a patch](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=789327) now, let's see whether it's acceptable to the maintainers.

In any case, this is not a Polari issue, so closing.

events.target_title: [feature request] always show help button
[feature request] always show help button

note.body:
> maybe, there is a background misunderstanding: with welcome page I mean the page which appears the very first time and only in that moment.

OK, so that was the missing bit. We do indeed disable the regular titlebar controls for the initial setup window, because the guided Cancel/Next/Done actions replace the stock close button. I'm afraid that the reasons for disabling those controls are stronger than giving GTK+ a fallback location for the app menu, so this is not going to change.

The alternatives we have boil down to:
- enabling the window's menubar instead, so GTK+ can put the menu there

    This isn't a great option, as a single-item menubar in a window designed to not use a traditional menubar will stick out like a sore thumb
- adding a dedicated Help button to the initial setup window (either unconditionally, or depending on whether the app menu is displayed)

    This is a more realistic option, but I don't think it is right to expose Help prominently where it isn't actually helpful - right now, we don't have any documentation at all for initial setup
- just accept that any action from the app menu is not available during initial setup

    I will go with this for now. Rethinking the app menu (and very likely replacing it with in-app UI) is on the agenda and may very well happen in time for 3.28. When this happens, it makes sense for us to keep the initial setup window in mind. But right now, adding an ad-hoc solution that may be obsoleted by updated design guidelines in a few months doesn't make much sense.

Category Determination

note.body:
Assuming your referring to the categories in apps-menu, and not the folders in the overview, the list is built based on the menu file `/etc/xdg/menus/gnome-application.menu`, following the [Freedesktop Menu Specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/menu-spec/menu-spec-1.0.html).

You can control the content of the menu using categories in the desktop files, but not all categories have any effect. You can edit that file by creating a copy in `~/.config/menus`, or by  adding another file in `~/.config/menus/gnome-applications-merged`.
Commonly, this is done using a tool such as Alacarte.

[RFE] Support server passwords for logging in to ZNC servers

note.body:
I had a similar problem as @tony yesterday (maybe the same?). Polari tried to connect for a long time and than gave up, with no error. At some point I come up with the idea that the reason might be the self-signed ssl certificate ZNC creates by default. I replaced it with a valid certificate from Let's Encrypt, Polari asked for a password and everything worked as expected. :smiley: 

No matter if it is the same problem or not, error reporting can probably be improved in this area. For example in my case a error that the SSL certificate is not valid (and maybe with a option to accept it anyway) would have saved a lot of time. Beside that I agree with the mockup above, setting a password directly during the network configuration is probably more straight forward for most users.

Handle ICS files

note.body:
> ICS files can come in two kinds: 1) ICS urls that are supposed to be kept and updated from the web, for example[1]: http://www.gnome.org/start/unstable/schedule.ics which we link as: webcal://www.gnome.org/start/unstable/schedule.ics to make subscribing easier (the browser won't try to download it locally before adding it) 2) ICS files that will be downloaded, and from which we want to only select certain items. For example, this FOSDEM schedule: https://fosdem.org/2015/schedule/track/embedded.ics For which you'd like to see a list of items, and select which of the items you want to add to your calendar

I would like to add another use case: You get a invitation for a meeting by email. In this case the ics file contains exactly one appointment you want to add to your calendar if you accept the appointment. It would be nice if gnome calendar would start if I click on such a ics file in my mail client, ask me to which calendar I want to import the appointment and add it to the calendar. At the moment I always jump to Evolution if I get a invitation to accept it and properly add it to the calendar (otherwise claws-mail is my mail client of choice). If Gnome Calendar would be able to handle it directly people could freely use the mail client of their choice and just send invitations to the calendar.

note.body:
> Are there any FreeBSD images out there that have recent GNOME stuff built? I'd also be interested in seeing if we can get gitlab C-I setup to run builds on FreeBSD.

This depends on what 'recent' means here.

If you want an image with latest stable GNOME (3.26), There are some LiveCD images built by me available on [sourceforge](https://sourceforge.net/projects/freebsd-gnome-livecd/files/). They are built from the latest development ports tree of FreeBSD GNOME team. Yes, 3.26 is still an in-development version on FreeBSD, and the version in the official FreeBSD ports is the old 3.18 release. The system image can be found at `data/system.uzip` in a LiveCD image. It is a uzip-compressed UFS filesystem image. Since the LiveCD image is built for previewing, testing and debugging the next version of GNOME that is going to be committed to FreeBSD ports, it includes many packages which may be considered bloated for use in a CI environment, such as kernel and kernel modules, debug symbols, fonts, graphics drivers.

If you want an image with latest unstable GNOME (3.27), there are none as far as I know. My plan is to get BuildStream to work on FreeBSD, but I don't know when I can complete it and it largely depends on my free time. If you want to track the progress, there is an [issue](https://gitlab.com/BuildStream/buildstream/issues/190) opened on GitLab. It is also possible to run JHBuild on FreeBSD to get a development environment, and it is what I use to test GNOME most of the time. We have a document on [wiki](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/Jhbuild/FreeBSD) which briefly describes steps to setup a JHBuild environment and lists many known and resolved issues for references, but it is likely to be incomplete because we seldom test these steps on a clean installation. Personally I have a much more complex `jhbuildrc` because I want to use the same configuration file on both FreeBSD and GNU/Linux. I can share it if you want it.

> I think the core issue here is fixed, and I added a workaround for autoreconf in commit 6e390b2de72c70c26758c1b42e655a687c2aa2a7.

This commit seems to make `/usr/local/bin` the only directory in `PATH`, which doesn't work when running `autogen.sh` because many programs used in shell scripts are installed in `/usr/bin` and `/bin` instead. Even if `autogen.sh` is not available and GNOME Builder runs `autoreconf` directly, it won't work because `autoreconf` is a shell script wrapper on FreeBSD, which requires `basename` (installed in `/usr/bin`) to run.

I probably didn't state the problem clearly enough. FreeBSD has a clear separation between the base system and third-party software. The base system is installed in `/usr` prefix, and packages, which are considered third-party software, must be installed in a different prefix. This rule also applies to OpenBSD and NetBSD. The default prefix for packages is `/usr/local` on FreeBSD, and all binary packages distributed by FreeBSD project are built with this default. The system is also configured to load libraries from `/usr/local/lib` and put `/usr/local/bin` in `PATH` by default. However, `/usr/local` is just a default value. It can be changed by users as long as they are willing to build all packages from FreeBSD ports themselves. FreeBSD ports maintainers don't hard-code `/usr/local` in Makefiles, and they usually patch things hard-coding `/usr/local` to the prefix set by users. If we hard-code `/usr/local` here, it is likely to be patched by the maintainer, which is not ideal because we want to keep the number of local patches as small as possible.

I think the best solution is to make it possible to change `PATH` used by GNOME Builder via `gsettings`, like what we already do for `ctags`. We can make the `PATH` default to `/bin`, `/usr/bin`, and the prefix used by GNOME Builder itself. We should also provide a meson option to allow changing the default during the build for special environments like JHBuild, which needs not only the prefix but also `/usr/local`.

> After testing `grep` on a FreeBSD Live-CD, it looks like the `--exclude` feature is not enough for us to get something similar to `--exclude-dir`. So we'll have to just take the slower path and rely on the loaded `IdeVcs` ignored file check.

After filing this bug, I found there is a program called [bsdgrep](https://wiki.freebsd.org/BSDgrep) on FreeBSD. It seems it is more GNU-compatible than the ancient version of GNU grep installed as `/usr/bin/grep`, so I think we can simply use bsdgrep on FreeBSD until the old GNU grep gets replaced.

events.target_title: cc.has_argument cannot be used to check linker arguments
cc.has_argument cannot be used to check linker arguments

note.body:
The only solution I can find is `cc.links`. I don't know whether meson will provide a better solution.

```
project('test', 'c')
cc = meson.get_compiler('c')
link_args = ['-Wl,-z,relro', '-Wl,-z,now', '-Wl,--verbose', '-Wl,--hello-world']
foreach link_arg : link_args
  cc.links('int main () { return 0; }', name: link_arg, args: link_arg)
endforeach
```

It seems to work correctly with both GCC and Clang:

```
The Meson build system
Version: 0.44.0
Native C compiler: gcc7 (gcc 7.3.0)
Checking if "-Wl,-z,relro" links: YES
Checking if "-Wl,-z,now" links: YES
Checking if "-Wl,--verbose" links: YES
Checking if "-Wl,--hello-world" links: NO
```

```
The Meson build system
Version: 0.44.0
Native C compiler: clang50 (clang 5.0.1)
Checking if "-Wl,-z,relro" links: YES
Checking if "-Wl,-z,now" links: YES
Checking if "-Wl,--verbose" links: YES
Checking if "-Wl,--hello-world" links: NO
```

>  I've tried to avoid terms like "external" or "non-GNOME", since this could be alienating and a bit constraining.

I very much agree with this. "External" sounds unfriendly but also technically incorrect, since being hosted on GNOME servers makes you "internal", in fact. In Damned Lies, we call projects hosted on freedesktop.org and the like "external". Also, the "GNOME" part in names like "GNOME-Infrastructure" is redundant, but the proposal seems to fix that.

LLVM 7.0 and MESA 17.4 + Wayland = broken mouse control

note.body:
This is due to EGLConfig handling. Assuming it's using cogl-winsys-egl.c's config call to get the EGLConfig, it asks for RGB to all be at least 1bpp, and 'don't care' alpha. So not really surprising that it's getting pretty random configs.

`EGL_NATIVE_VISUAL_ID` is a valid config attribute match, mapping to GBM format IDs. Given that `XRGB8888` is hardcoded right now, passing that in as a fixed native visual ID to match is probably the best thing. There are patches on the list at the moment to enable `XBGR8888` for Nouveau, so just matching the colour channel sizes without matching ordering would result in that breaking as well.

[PATCH] Lua 5.2 and 5.3 support.

note.body:
Honestly the Lua plugin loader just doesn't seem to be used by anyone. This was also seen with JavaScript and is in part why the Seed and GJS loaders were removed. Looking at popular distributions shows that the lua5.1 loader isn't being packaged. GitHub shows only 3 users, one project is commercial and the other two enable the lua5.1 loader but don't seem to actually use it. One even has a number of example plugins, but every single one of them is in Python. Which I can understand, why would you use a plugin loader that you (and possibly your users) have to manually build?

Considering the lua5.1 loader was released almost 4 years ago (will be by the time of the next GNOME release) I think it is time to say goodbye and remove it. Without the burden of the Lua plugin loader I can implement some upcoming features without spending time on an unused plugin loader.

Thoughts?

events.target_title: Use Unicode in translatable strings

note.body:
At some point yes, unfortunately this has been complicated with my application for Social Security Disability.

Now, this commit may break the tests which I haven't been able to check on as my build machine is "a bit" outdated. Until I can verify that the test suite doesn't use these strings in any way I cannot commit this change.

events.target_title: [PATCH] Lua 5.2 and 5.3 support.

note.body:
Question which "distros moved on with newer lua versions"? I've looked at multiple popular distro releases (including older ones) but I haven't found it packaged by any of them.

There is also the issue that searching online, I can't find anyone actually *using* it. Just because something works doesn't mean it should be kept. If that were true we would keep Python 2 support until the end of time. If the Lua loader was going to be used by now it would have. Not the mention that compared to PyGObject there are very few users of LGI.

The features I'm talking about are upcoming capabilities that have taken many hours to develop. The maintenance burden is unnecessary at this point and I don't want to be slowed down supporting a loader that is all but unused and not packaged. Looking back, this is the same issue that happened with Seed/GJS and yet there are more application that could benefit from a GJS loader than an LGI loader.

I'm all for multiple loader but they must be high quality and usable. I've looked at other language bindings it the hopes of adding them but at those times they were not usable in production. Yes, I removed both JavaScript loaders and with good reason. Seed was no longer maintained and had been for quite sometime. GJS on the other hand was being maintained but had been broken for *months* and no one noticed. I'm guessing if distros were *actually* building the loader they would had reported it. It was ultimately removed because the loader needed a massive rewrite to work and it didn't seem worthwhile, after all who cared?

Now, LGI is a good language binding but it is also not being maintained much anymore. Looking at the repository shows that there have only been 35 commits in the last 2 years. To put that in comparison PyGObject, GJS, Vala and gtkmm have had about the same number of commits in the last two months. Having another language to support means that any features added to one loader also need to be available in all others. The only difference is that the work done on the Python loader will *actually* be used.

I would love to add more **high quality** and **maintained** loaders which are actually used by the community but right now Lua is not one of them. If you are working on a patch to add a loader which does not fit the above I would recommend that you instead spend you time developing a GJS loader. Hopefully the improved quality of the bindings, its official status and the huge number of JavaScript developers will mean it is used.

events.target_title: Allow to write a plugin manager in bindings (for example, Python)

note.body:
I'm going to be fairly blunt here: WTF. This is my project, there are an amazing 7 translation commits since my last release. That does not give you the right or authority to take my maintainership away from me without so much as an email.

Just because you decided to write a patch implementing a feature I turned down does not mean you can suddenly appear here and start taking over. Again, saving a few writes the first time an application is loaded, or one if optimized, is not something I'm interested in.

Please keep to your own projects unless the *proper* steps are taken.

Files ignores "Sort folders before files" on search
Files ignores "Sort folders before files" on search

note.body:
@csoriano can we please have some more investigation on what is the preferable way to go with that, before that change made final?

for example in my personal use i rarely will search directly for a file. typically i'm searching for a folder that i know it contains the file i'm looking for, and then i will perform a second search for a file. that is because file names are often matching lots of results, so getting 50 results wont help to quickly discover what you're looking for, and current directory (eg $HOME) will hardly contain that file anyway

when im looking directly for file names, is most usually when im expecting to find multiple results rather one, so it again depth ranking isn't very useful 
 
i understand there is not right or wrong here, i'm just trying to figure out whats the most used case for people. however this change still ignores a strong setting, people that prefer mixed ordering can have this option disabled for all views (which is also a default GNOME setting), plus if next FilesApp versions can deal better with debt ranking, this change wont be even a nessecary

another solution i can think of is that this option can be "live" only on list view with a sort option on treeview header

events.target_title: Files ignores "Sort folders before files" on search

note.body:
@csoriano 
> That's sounds strange. Also the goal is to find a file, if we are failing to do so we should improve that, not searching for workarounds. Feel free to open new issues with specific use cases that are failing to you to find your file. 

it is not strange, neither is failing. assume you're looking for $HOME/Projects/my-project/README.md file

if you are in $HOME and perform a search for "readme.md, it will return you a big number of results, so it wont help you to quickly find what you're looking for

if you are in $Home/Projects and perform a search for "readme" again you're get a big number of results (since all projects have a README.md). moreover in grid view you wont be able to say what README.md belongs where, and in list view the eye wont scan fast enough the result you're looking for

so what i meant is when im in $HOME and i want to find $HOME/Projects/my-project/README.md file, i will first perform a search for "my-project", and when i get into that directory i will perform a second search for "README" file. and if i dont want to display folders i can use the file extension, like "README.md" 

my point is that i will rarely need to search for specific files, 4-5 directories up, instead i will first navigate some folders inside and then i will perform a second search, that it will limit the results, and it will make easier to find what are you looking for. besides normally people remember their folders structure (and folder names), rather file names

but this change actually makes that harder, because you will get files before folders so the navigation with arrows (search, arrow down, enter!) will become slower

> What is depth ranking? 


i mean the tree-depth hierarchy a file is. i thought you were using the term "ranking", so i used that to, to make it more clear. not with a big success apparently :)

i want to add a last point. if that change becomes final, then it will "force" me to never use "Sort folders before files" option again, because i dont (and i doubt i can adjust) want to work with two different views, one with mixed files and folders (search view) and one with folders always on top (normal view), specially when **the search view is actually the most used view**

regarding the last, it will be almost the same as completely dropping that option for sorting folders first

Hi Yuri

I think this is a chrome-gnome-shell/flatpak issue. I have tried a few things since I opened this issue - see below:

I have for example got flash-plugin working on the flatpak version of firefox by placing the file libflashplayer.so in the hidden location in my home directory:
.var/app/org.mozilla.FirefoxNightly/.mozilla/plugins. Basically by doing this I installed flash-plugin within the firefox sandbox.

In a similar way I placed the executable file chrome-gnome-shell inside a folder called bin in .var/app/org.mozilla.FirefoxNightly/.mozilla/ 

Also I placed the file org.gnome.chrome_gnome_shell.json within a folder called native-messaging-hosts in .var/app/org.mozilla.FirefoxNightly/.mozilla/ and amended the file so the path to the executable in the file points to the new location .var/app/org.mozilla.FirefoxNightly/.mozilla/bin

This works up to a point. When I now go to https://extensions.gnome.org/ I don't get the usual message "Although GNOME Shell integration extension is running, native host connector is not detected. Refer documentation for instructions about installing connector". I now just get the message "undefined". Firefox now recognizes that chrome-gnome-shell is installed but I guess the problem lies with the fact that chrome-gnome-shell cannot see out of the sandbox to see what extensions are installed.

events.target_title: [RFE] Support for Fedora Account System
[RFE] Support for Fedora Account System

note.body:
It's just about branding. Nowadays, our OpenID portal accepts the Kerberos TGT if it's available and will automatically log users in. All of our web applications use the OpenID portal for login (except the Fedora Account Service application, but that's a special case).

So I think just branding the generic Kerberos account is fine (though I don't want to *replace* that account, since there are probably other uses for it). Just providing a duplicate of it that takes username, appends `@FEDORAPROJECT.ORG` to it and uses the password to get the TGT. (I don't want the users to have to know about the `@FEDORAPROJECT.ORG` part of the username.

GitG should filter/hide reference outside of refs/head
GitG should filter/hide reference outside of refs/head

note.body:
You explicitly made git to list all existing refs by using `--all`:

```
--all
    Pretend as if all the refs in refs/, along with HEAD, are listed on the command line as <commit>.
```

I can't see a reason to use `--all` in a normal coding workflow so it would make sense to me that gitg would behave the same way, at least by default.

> is it possible to store info outside refs?

No, it's the only way I can think of to store and exchange data using git without adding files along the normal source code in a branch.

> or config a exclude pattern for git log programmatically?

As far as I can tell, that's not possible.

events.target_title: GitG should filter/hide reference outside of refs/head

note.body: Another possible way would be to have `gitg` lazy load or paginate the list of refs instead of being unresponsive for 15+ seconds when the number of ref is high (10k in my tests).

events.target_title: Resolve "Split out a backend library"

note.body:
So my last two comments were aimed at commits  f679abd1 and 97a4e7b5 - it seems I need to learn how to use gitlab's interface.

@esodan How did you determine who to email? Did you use git blame to find all the authors, or just use the emails at the top of the files? If the latter is the case that is insufficient to re-license, you need to contact *every* author. Running git blame is the first step, then you need to check if that change was significant, if it is just correcting whitespace or something trivial you need to dig into the history to find the original author. Relicensing is not so simple that you can send out a MR and ask for it to be merged 4 days later. This talk is quite informative if I remember correctly (it has been several years since I listened to it) http://faif.us/cast/2013/sep/04/0x42/)

> Clause 13, allows to relicensing to any future version, as for FSF, so I think LGPL Version 2.1 is the better choice for the library.

Just because users can choose to use the library under a later version does not necessarily mean it is a good idea to release this code under an earlier version with an 'or later' clause. If the earlier version is unclear in certain areas or permits things like  tivoization which we might not want to allow then it would be better to choose a later version.

@robertroth As I understand it from this thread only three authors have responded and only two of them have agreed so far. So I don't think you can dual license as you suggested at the moment as that would still be changing the license without the author's permission.

Best Wishes

Phillip

events.target_title: Resolve "Split out a backend library"

note.body:
> @pwood I didn't suggest to dual-license anything 

@robertroth sorry I must have misunderstood what you meant by “Can we dual-license the lib until we replace all the code which the authors do not agree?”

I agree it would be good to wait and hopefully get some discussion from other authors, I'm happy to go with LGPL2.1 if that is the consensus but I think it would be worth discussing the advantages and disadvantages first. As I see it the advantages of going for LGPLv3+ are: 1) it prevents the software being used in locked down devices; 2) it is explicit about patents; and 3) it is drafted to apply more easily outside of the US legal system.

I just hand a quick look at the [blame view for lib/math-equation.vala](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-calculator/blame/master/lib/math-equation.vala) and there are some authors (elitalobo <loboelita@gmail.com>, Daniel Renninghoff <daniel.renninghoff@gmail.com> and probably others - I only looked at that one file and didn't scroll down very far) that are not in the list of people contacted above.

Best Wishes

Phillip

note.body: No problem! Its being used to [override the Tweener module](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/a039f7db996d7e049228a52eecba7513b1f4a2db/js/ui/overrides.js#L187) in Cinnamon. This [particular patch](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/pull/3662) was made so opacity tweens couldn't go below 0, or over 255. I moved the CJS patches to Cinnamon itself, so Cinnamon can run with GJS. If exposing that as a public API isn't the intention here, I understand.

events.target_title: Determine GSource priority of promise resolution

note.body: I've written some promise reliant code for Cinnamon that ended up being slow on GJS 1.48 and 1.50. When there are multiple promises queued up, it seems to take a few seconds longer for 20-30 promises to resolve with `Promise.all` using `G_PRIORITY_DEFAULT_IDLE`. When set to a 0 priority, its closer to the performance I've seen in NodeJS and the browser. Not sure if that's the best approach though.

events.target_title: Tweener: Add min/max properties

note.body:
I would be happy to help merge the CJS patches. I don't think there are a lot of them. There's the tweener patch we're discussing, [_signalHandlerIsConnected in signals.js](https://github.com/linuxmint/cjs/commit/a029c273bb195ff9e943ecae922c5a8f7282e004), and my [promise tweak](https://github.com/linuxmint/cjs/pull/61/commits/d34f98a15baf19bcbc49c448d8101bfd438cc053) forcing promises to run with a 0 priority (#1).

I haven't written tests for the GJS environment before, but probably need to start learning.

note.body:
Yup, I can confirm that the issue is reproducible. I am positive that's the reason why this is broken, the resource path being different for webapp mode (log slightly edited for readability):

```
G_MESSAGES_DEBUG=all epiphany --application-mode --profile="/home/aperez/.config/epiphany/app-epiphany-mastodon-d8951096e3eedf7e3a438281a15f522b2bdee0f9" https://mastodon.social/web/getting-started
(epiphany:5244): Gdk-DEBUG: 17:35:07.724: Compositor prefers decoration mode 'server'
(epiphany:5244): Gtk-DEBUG: 17:35:07.743: Connecting to session manager
(epiphany:5244): Gtk-DEBUG: 17:35:07.746: Failed to get the GNOME session proxy: The name org.gnome.SessionManager is not owned
(epiphany:5244): Gtk-DEBUG: 17:35:07.746: Failed to get the Xfce session proxy: The name org.xfce.SessionManager is not owned
(epiphany:5244): dzl-theme-manager-DEBUG: 17:35:07.820: Including CSS overrides from resource:///org/gnome/dazzle/themes/
(epiphany:5244): dzl-css-provider-DEBUG: 17:35:07.820: Loading css overrides "resource:///org/gnome/dazzle/themes/Arc-solid.css"
(epiphany:5244): dzl-theme-manager-DEBUG: 17:35:07.823: Loading icon resources from /org/gnome/dazzle/icons/
```

I *think* there may be some API in `DzlCssProvider` to specify the base resource path, or alternatively we can expose the same CSS resources under `/org/gnome/Epiphany/WebApp/themes/` with an alias rule in the `.gresources.xml` file.

events.target_title: GStreamer 1.14 compatibily and lighter build support

note.body:
Plugins usually don't contain the API version in the filename, AFAIK, at least for the upstream plugins.
I use both macOS and Linux, the issue is platform-independent. This was mentioned in the release notes BTW:
https://gstreamer.freedesktop.org/releases/1.14/

The default plugin entry point has changed. This will only affect plugins that are recompiled against new GStreamer headers. Binary plugins using the old entry point will continue to work. However, plugins that are recompiled must have matching plugin names in GST_PLUGIN_DEFINE and filenames, as the plugin entry point for shared plugins is now deduced from the plugin filename. This means you can no longer have a plugin called foo living in a file called libfoobar.so or such, the plugin filename needs to match. This might cause problems with some external third party plugin modules when they get rebuilt against GStreamer 1.14.

That's why my patch renames the plugin and the library filename :)

events.target_title: Empty "OS Updates" details

note.body:
```
$ find ~/.cache -name flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
/home/username/.cache/gnome-software/3.26/flatpak/installation-tmp/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
```
```
$ ls -Al /home/christian/.cache/gnome-software/3.26/flatpak/installation-tmp/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
-rw-------. 1 username username 2888 14. Jan 17:42 /home/username/.cache/gnome-software/3.26/flatpak/installation-tmp/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
```
Opening the file with `less` works fine.

But on the other hand, 
```
$ locate flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
/home/username/.cache/gnome-software/3.26/flatpak/installation-tmp/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
/home/username/.local/share/flatpak/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
/var/lib/flatpak/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
```
```
$ ls -Al /home/username/.local/share/flatpak/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
-rw-------. 1 username username 2888  4. Sep 2017  /home/christian/.local/share/flatpak/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
```
```
$ ls -Al /var/lib/flatpak/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
-rw-------. 1 root root 2888 29. Jul 2017  /var/lib/flatpak/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg
```

So the key in `/var/lib/flatpak/repo/flathub.trustedkeys.gpg` cannot be read. This is expected and a known bug in flatpak which does not handle umask correctly: https://github.com/flatpak/flatpak/issues/1496

events.target_title: Cannot install gnome-feeds flatpak

note.body:
I found the problem! It is an issue with [`gnome-software-local-file.desktop`](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-software/blob/master/src/gnome-software-local-file.desktop.in) and xdg-open.

The correct way to open a `.flatpakref` is like this:
```
gnome-software --local-filename=/home/sebas/Downloads/org.gabmus.gfeeds.flatpakref
```

The `gnome-software-local-file.desktop` file, which is used to open `.flatpakref`s from file managers or browsers, contains the following line:
```
Exec=gnome-software --local-filename=%f
```

Here, the `%f` is supposed to be replaced with the filename that should be opened. However, xdg-open only substitutes `%f` if they occur as their own argument, i.e. if it is surrounded by spaces. [(src)](https://gitlab.freedesktop.org/xdg/xdg-utils/blob/bfcefa162b1dcd6d62e193019969ff2f5ff331cf/scripts/xdg-open.in#L290)

So if I change the line in `gnome-software-local-file.desktop` to the following (`=` replaced by ` `), it **does** work:
```
Exec=gnome-software --local-filename %f
```

Now I think that xdg-open is in the wrong here, because the [Desktop Entry Specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/desktop-entry-spec/desktop-entry-spec-latest.html#exec-variables) does not mention that field codes (e.g. `%f`) should be surrounded by spaces. But since xdg-open is the de-facto cross-DE standard I think we should adapt our desktop file so it works there.

region: All input sources should be selectable irrespective of which locales have been generated

note.body:
Gunnar is completely right.
This is an i18n regression: input methods in particular do not depend on the user locale.

(Longer term: this is actually another example of why input method and keyboard layout configuration should really be handled separately.)

However even for keyboard layouts: yes typically most users would use a keyboard corresponding to their locale (or vice versa), but this is not always the case. People and computers move around: one might have a PC from a particular country or region but wish to use it for a different language/locale. Of course ideally we could warn users: "Your keyboard layout does not support all the characters of your chosen language", say.

Of course it is perfectly fine to suggest first the keyboard layouts that match the user'a locale, but the others should still be available to choose if needed.

Internal hyperlinks to anchors in ePub do not work

note.body:
The second one depends on how the method `resource_callback` in `GepubWidget` works.

It takes a link like `epub://something.xhtml` and uses the part after `epub://` to find the resource it needs to load. However, when you have an anchor you get `something.xhtml#anchor` which doesn't exist in the archive.

There would also be a second problem with that anchor. And is that after loading the GBytes into the view, you don't know about that anchor anymore. The `load-change` signal triggers `docready_cb` which calls `reload_length_cb` when load is finished. When everything inside that function finishes (which is done asynchronously in JS), we should be calling `webkit_web_view_load_uri` with the anchor probably...

I need a hand to understand if I found out something or not.

events.target_title: Minor padding + alignment issues

note.body:
Hi @csoriano,

I'm sorry in advance for the long post :smile: 

 
I tried to reconstruct the X,Y values used in the call below for the first icon

    icon_set_position(icon, X, Y)

so

    X = x + position->x_offset = ICON_PAD_LEFT + x_offset

`position->x_offset` is the one below

    position->x_offset = (icon_width - (icon_bounds.x1 - icon_bounds.x0)) / 2;

So it looks something like the `xoff` in the picture below

    bounds.x0/y0
    +-------------------------------------
    |      icon_bounds.x0/y0          .
    |<-xoff->+---------------+<-xoff->.
    |        |    folder     |        .
    |        |               |        .
    |        +---------------+        .
    |               icon_bounds.x1/y1 .
    |<---------icon_width------------>.

the computation of `y_offset` is different

    position->y_offset = icon_bounds.y0 - icon_bounds.y1;

being `y0 < y1`, it is always negative and it works as a compensation for the `y` value when laying down the icon. Moreover it's exactly the same (except sign) than position->height

    position->height = icon_bounds.y1 - icon_bounds.y0;

I guess that, if `y` is the *baseline*, that is, the line on the bottom of the icon, and being (for the first row of icons)

    baseline = y = padding + max_height_above

`y_offset` seems necessary to point to the top of the icon (to the coordinate y0)


    |  icon_bounds.x0/.y0
    |       +---------+    -> y - position.height
    |       |         |
    |       |         |
    +-------+---------+-----> y
                    1(x,y)

`max_height_above` comes from

    height_above = icon_bounds.y1 - bounds.y0;
    max_height_above = MAX(height_above, max_height_above) /* summary of the real code */

but `bounds.y0` is always the same as `icon_bounds.y0` (I g_print-ed them), so `height_above` is equal to `position.height`

This means that the Y coordinate in icon_set_position is

    Y = y                                 + y_offset
    Y = (ICON_PAD_TOP + max_height_above) + y_offset
    Y = ICON_PAD_TOP + max_height_above   - position.height
    Y = ICON_PAD_TOP

but 

    X = ICON_PAD_LEFT + x_offset

so, even if ICON_PAD_LEFT and ICON_PAD_RIGHT are the same, the actual pad on the side is bigger than the one on the top.

Before starting to code, I've also thought some other ways of solving this problem. But all of the solutions I've found includes renaming or moving the colliding file temporarily.
If any method exists without these operations, I'd love to see it as well.

Real problem is we have files named as "Image01" and "Image02", how can we rename "Image01" to "Image02" without using a temporary form? Ordering the list cannot solve this case.

events.target_title: batch-rename: fix batch renaming logic for colliding filenames

note.body:
I thought moving files to /tmp, but on some systems /tmp is mounted at another HDD partition instead of tmpfs. Renaming big files could be problematic, maybe /tmp is not big enough for that file etc. 
Also, moving to /tmp, moving back to original place could take a lot of time.

We can change random string generator with a more appropriate one, if we have any.

Any opinions?

events.target_title: Games doesn't build

note.body:
So, we have two options here:

1. [Switch to desmume2015.](https://gitlab.gnome.org/exalm/gnome-games/tree/desmume-option1) I've also unpinned the commit. Whatever was the reason to pin it, it builds and works fine now.
2. [Switch to new desmume.](https://gitlab.gnome.org/exalm/gnome-games/tree/desmume-option2)

For some reason the new core is _really_ slow for me, and generally works much worse. :/
So I'd prefer the former option.

Edit: It seems the main feature of the new desmume is optional opengl support. It works in RetroArch, and is faster than software rendering, but both are slower for me than desmume2015.
There's also [desmume2014](https://github.com/libretro/desmume2014), but I'm not sure what's the difference from desmume2015.

@aplazas @theawless opinions?

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
Another spot where I saw a reproducible memory increase:

1) Note the current memory usage of gnome-shell.

2) Run /usr/bin/notify-send "This is notification" 20 times and notice that gnome-shell memory usage increased by 10MB.

3) Open the message tray and clear each notification individually.

4) Open looking class and run a manual System.gc() and notice that the memory usage did not go down again.

5) Go back to step 2 and repeat.

events.target_title: Can't accept a transfer if notification moves into the tray
appstream metadata in legacy location

note.body:
Hey @lkundrak :-)

> The [specification](https://www.freedesktop.org/software/appstream/docs/chap-Metadata.html#sect-Metadata-GenericComponent) suggests that both /usr/share/appdata and /usr/share/metainfo are supported, not recommending the former one new "new software components".

I think it might be time to change that wording - that paragraph hasn't been touched for a while since I wrote it and might be misleading now.

AppStream itself (with the libappstream library) supported the `/usr/share/metainfo/` path for quite a while, but it was only made the official path in the 0.9.4 release, which was released in 2016-04-18.

The other relevant piece, appstream-glib, supports the metainfo path since version 0.5.14, released in 2016-04-20 shortly after, but this one only made it default about a year later.

For AppStream, the most relevant thing however is not the version of the AppStream libraries that the distro ships with, but the version of the libraries it uses to generate the metadata on the server-side. This is why every Ubuntu release that supports AppStream also supports the metainfo path, and would even do so if their AppStream library versions were too old.

so, tl;dr: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS as well as 18.04 LTS fully support the metainfo path and even prefer it over the other one. Even 16.04 LTS already had AppStream 0.9.4.
As for RHEL 7, I can't say for certain but I am very sure Richard Hughes generates data for it with the freshest appstream-glib anyway. Even if not, a Google search showed that apparently appstream-glib is at version 0.6.10 in RHEL 7 at the moment, which handles the metainfo path easily.
The appdata path really was a stopgap solution when we expected AppStream's scope to be much smaller and didn't know other projects used it for XML occasionally.

tl;dr 2: Please use the metainfo path, it's the right thing to do and the Lintian warning makes absolute sense. I should probably make the wording in the spec less strong and include some more detail on when to use the old path, to make that decision easier.
Nowadays, I think unless you have some really old possibly company-internal distro, there is no reason to use the old path.

events.target_title: Cannot push video-subtitles Serbian translation to the upstream repository
Would it be possible to user Free software terminolgy to mark non-free software?  "NonFree" instead of "Proprietary" for example

note.body:
My recollection of conversation with designers was that the wording was chosen not really for philosophical reasons but for the common "free vs. libre" confusion. Most (in fact, in the case of Fedora, I'm pretty sure _all_) of the software which might be included here is free of charge, so "non free" could confuse people who are not versed in free and open source software already.

For Fedora, at least, I *do* prefer that we put a little bit of philosophy in the UI. We want to advance free software. I'm open to the idea that making access to all software easy helps advance the platform and therefore free software in the long run, but I do think we should make the distinction clear and not buried. I guess where exactly a given design hits the line between "clear" and "annoyingly lecturesome" (or even "frightening") is quite subjective.

Anyway, I wish there were a good short term we could use. "Non-Free" alone has the cost problem. "Non-Libre" is confusing — and things like "FOSS" or "FLOSS" are even more jargonish. We could say "Not Open Source", but then we get into the Open Source vs. Free Software quagmire.

So, I can't really think of any word for the badge other than "Proprietary".

And, in absence of that, I think we'll need to keep the education and advancement of free and open source software to the short hover text, to the text when enabling non-free and open source sources, and to the link target page. Let's focus on making those really excellent and useful.

events.target_title: Better differentiation of users in the chat backlog

note.body:
Hi all; I switched to Polari a little while back and nick differentiation is the big feature I miss. Previously, in HexChat, I used nick coloration (with a lot of other config tweaks which Polari basically does by default).

Custom color markers is a nice mockup. It's the best of the three above.

However, I do like what Fractal is doing with the circular badges, when there isn't an Matrix icon available. It uses a generated color (from a palette, it seems) and the initials of the person (generally just one letter). A second letter could be used if the nick is `StudlyCapped` or uses a `non_letter` character. Additionally, some people use #s on their names, like andreasn1 (could be A1).

That all said, the `/me` line is a little weird in this screenshot, though.

![irc-screenshot-2](/uploads/a1e290b5416f156f31552d026d096cf5/irc-screenshot-2.png)

(I also like the line spacing better too — it builds on what Polari is doing, but adjusts the vertical spacing a little for multiple messages... but I vastly prefer what Polari does with "ambient" timestamps. :smile:)

Provide get_color methods in VTE
Provide get_color methods in VTE

note.body:
Is get_color a private method because I don't see it in the documentation and it's not in the gir file?

https://developer.gnome.org/vte/unstable/VteTerminal.html

With regards to the custom background drawing, tilix leverages the new set_clear_background method to take over the background drawing of VTE. This enables features like drawing badges, background images, etc. When the user sets the color via the tilix preferences tilix can of course draw the color correctly because tilix know what it is. When the user changes the background color via an escape sequence tilix doesn't know.

So I'm asking for the equivalent of the set_color methods that return the color, i.e.

get_color_foreground
get_color_background
get_colors

Technically I really only need to the get_color_background but it makes sense to support the others since they can be changed with escape sequences as well.

events.target_title: Provide get_color methods in VTE

note.body:
I'm curious, does VTE maintain a single background color or does it maintain two background colors, the one set by the wrapping emulator and the one that is actually used?

If it's the latter case, I think naming it something like "for_draw", "actual", "current", etc is fine since it is indicative of what it means. If vte only maintains one color, I'd probably just stick with ```vte_terminal_get_bg_color``` to match the setter.

My two cents...

events.target_title: Implement overlay scrollbars

note.body:
Just to be clear, tilix is not doing anything custom or special. It's just giving an option to use an overlay scrollbar instead of the normal one but it's using the normal GTK way of hooking such things up. Any other terminal emulator could choose to do the same.

Having said that, there a few minor VTE issues with overlay scrollbars but I'm not sure if it's the intent of VTE to formally support them. These minor issues is why tilix has an option for users to switch between the two.

events.target_title: Add action & info bar

note.body:
> Of course, all of this is dependent on double-click remaining the default...

Not necessarily. This would work with “click to select, click again to open”: 

* A single click on a file selects it (even if other files are already selected).
* While a file is selected, the mouse pointer becomes the hand cursor :point_up_2: , and a single click opens the file.
* Double-clicking a (not-yet-selected) file behaves like 2 separate clicks: selects the file, then opens it.

You can open a file without double-clicking and without moving the pointer to a separate button. If you are able to double-click, you can open the file that way.

Keyboard shortcuts window is too big
Promote pippin's patreon work on GEGL

note.body:
Do we know who our target audience is? For example the text on https://www.gimp.org/news/ is usually a bit technical. I assume we want to target a wider demographic, but I also wonder who these people are. Are they people who have some degree of familiarity with image processing? Are they just enthusiastic passers-by who might want to throw in a few bucks? I think this will influence how we word the text.

Also, a quick note that the original text pulls and summarizes content and figures (eg., the commit percentage) from various gimp.org PR material and news items that have appeared over the months. So, one can go back and figure out other ways to word things.

Mentioning non-destructive editing is tricky. GIMP is famously not non-destructive; it isn't going to be non-destructive in the next few years; and it is a high profile TODO item for GIMP. GNOME Photos is non-destructive, but most people know GEGL in the context of GIMP. So, loosely mentioning non-destructive editing can be misleading.

Another high profile thing that GIMP didn't have (at least the stable releases) is support for higher bit-depths. This is something that GEGL has famously solved in GIMP master, and is the reason why it is taking so long to release GIMP 2.10.

In other words, those who follow GIMP know what "higher bit-depth" means and they know that GIMP isn't non-destructive. It is, kind of, like those who follow GNOME have at least heard the terms HiPPI/HiDPI and Wayland somewhere.

I wouldn't completely axe the part about colour management. The recent addition of colour management is a pretty big milestone. I'd suggest replacing the non-destructive editing bits with a passing reference to colour management.

Thanks for working on this, and for all the suggestions! Much appreciated.

events.target_title: Folder with dot file shows as empty

note.body:
The general concept I'd like to follow for Files is to not allow to break the system by default. Majority of File's users will not be creating dotfiles or even be familiar with the concept of hidden files. Things like app config and data silos should be safe from deletion, unless going through an explicit hoop.

I don't like the idea of warning there might be hidden files before deletion, because of habituation (same reason we undo rather than warn). Adding extra noise to the folder empty label doesn't seem too compelling either, because a single file + hidden files are just as (un)likely case. Showing 'contains hidden files' everywhere becomes noise as well and emphasises functionality that I don't think we should promote. 

My take is that if people are familiar with, and use hidden files, they enable them for the view and we allow them to shoot themselves in the foot. Just like you have to live with recursive rm being potentially destructive, not having undo or trash to recover from it, I'd simply not special case dealing with hidden files other than preventing people to dive into dangerous locations. By default we don't expose config folders for example. Similarly I wouldn't expose app data silos in Files.

events.target_title: Key repeat settings are hard to find, confusing, and hard to test

note.body:
Thanks for your feedback, @teknico. Sorry it was not warmly received. I think part of your removed comment was relevant, though, namely that programs like Midnight Commander would become less usable without appropriate key-repeat settings (whether they are removed altogether or are unusably slow/fast).

I also think that reversing the Speed slider is a better solution than renaming it.

I've attached a mock-up that addresses my last 4 points:

![key-repeat-mockup](/uploads/d8c8d2e005be6ddda1925325b735aa0e/key-repeat-mockup.png)

The Speed slider is reversed and there are three new elements: the delay/speed value, the ticks on the speed slider, and the test entry box. Considering the GNOME HIG guideline "Keep user interface complexity to a minimum", I'll note that each of these make the experience better. The values make explicit what the slider does, the ticks point the user to preferred values, and the entry box lets them test the settings without having to close the window. I'm only concerned that users might be confused why the ticks are preferred values, that is, they might not understand the relationship to screen refresh rates.

Also note that the speed slider shows characters-per-second, rather than millisecond values. I think this is simpler for humans to comprehend, but it requires a conversion in the background. (Note, however, that I made a mistake in my mockup; `26` is the millisecond value, which corresponds to ~38 cps).

events.target_title: Key repeat settings are hard to find, confusing, and hard to test

note.body:
If the actual ms or cps values are not desired, we could take a cue from other settings, such as 'Typing Assist' or 'Click Assist', which have generic "short" and "long" labels on either side of the slider:

![Click Assist settings](/uploads/705f840e9c98087927622054b650b2cf/Screenshot_from_2018-08-02_17-28-55.png)

I also noticed that the 'Cursor Blinking' setting has the same problematic "Speed" slider as with 'Repeat Keys' (lower value is faster); if one is fixed, both should be.

events.target_title: Improve the highlighting and notes user experience

note.body:
I want to add that in the version I'm using (3.30.1), there are (at least) three ways to highlight in addition to using the toolbar:

1. Select text, bring up the context menu and click "Highlight Selected Text"
2. Select text then hit Ctrl-h
3. Hit Ctrl-h then highlight text

(3) is in the "highlight mode", the same as clicking the toolbar button. Arguably (1) and (2) are more useful because a user can fix an incorrect selection before creating the highlight annotation, but in any case your proposed fix would supersede this "highlight mode".

(Aside: the Ctrl-h keyboard shortcut is not hinted on the context menu nor shown in the "Keyboard Shortcuts" help window (which for me is in the app menu, but I guess that will change soon). I only discovered it when a web search turned up this: https://askubuntu.com/a/1078796/721623)

And I want to include two more points for improving the user experience, considering that it takes 6 clicks to change a single highlight's color, and 4-5 clicks to change the type (strikeout, underline, etc.):

* Provide a way to select annotation color before highlighting (related: #1126)
* Make other highlight types (strikeout, underline, etc.) equally accessible with a keyboard shortcut or button

events.target_title: Handle 'Persistent-Auth: false' when provided by the server

note.body:
I guess that since it is using the same connection, libsoup thinks it doesn't need to authenticate again (thus the missing header).

For reference, the Persistent-Auth feature is documented on: 
* https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd341152.aspx
* https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ee393311.aspx

However, libsoup is
* acting as if persistent-auth-value is 1 (but `Persistent-Auth: false`)
* when it receives a 401, it is not setting persistent-auth-value to 0 (or it is setting it but not retrying?)

I wonder if when using an asynchronous session the header is not recognized properly, thus treating it as persistent-auth-value=1 when using NTLM.

events.target_title: Night Light only affects one half of tiled 5K displays (Dell UP2715K, Nvidia 390)

note.body:
As far as I can tell, all code paths in gsd-color use colord to enumerate displays etc., but changing the temperature happens through a call to gnome_rr_crtc_set_gamma. OK, diving into the next library... :)

Edit: libgnome-desktop then uses DBus to call into mutter's `meta-monitor-manager.c`/`meta_monitor_manager_handle_set_crtc_gamma`, which then presumably branches into `x11/meta-monitor-manager-xrandr.c`, which eventually calls XRRSetCrtcGamma.

Edit: And somewhere down the road, the X server calls the KMS API drmModeCrtcSetGamma. I'm not sure at which point the abstraction of having a tiled screen breaks. I can change each half's gamma just fine using the xrandr command line tool, so I don't think it's a problem at the driver level.

events.target_title: Fix crash when a modal dialog closes while its parent is grabbed

note.body:
I saw this in a real world application of mine which led me to make this minimal reproduction code using qt-python / PySide2:

```python
#!/usr/bin/python3

from PySide2 import QtGui, QtCore, QtWidgets

class CrashOnTopWindow(QtWidgets.QMainWindow):
    def __init__(self, parent):
        super().__init__(parent=parent)
        self.setWindowModality(QtCore.Qt.WindowModal)
        self.setWindowFlags(self.windowFlags() |\
            QtCore.Qt.Dialog | QtCore.Qt.WindowStaysOnTopHint)

        self.label = QtWidgets.QLabel(
            "ignore this. dont grab or close this window.")
        self.label.setWordWrap(True)
        self.setCentralWidget(self.label)

        QtCore.QTimer.singleShot(15000, lambda: self.close())

class TestMainWindow(QtWidgets.QMainWindow):
    def __init__(self):
        super().__init__()
        self.setWindowTitle(" >> GRAB AND DRAG HERE. <<")
        self.box = QtWidgets.QVBoxLayout()
        label = QtWidgets.QLabel("Grab and drag this window around. " +
            "Don't let it go before the crash!")
        label.setWordWrap(True)
        self.setMinimumSize(300, 500)
        self.box.addWidget(label)
        self.box.addStretch(1)
        w = QtWidgets.QWidget()
        w.setLayout(self.box)
        self.setCentralWidget(w)

        QtCore.QTimer.singleShot(500, self.do_it)

    def do_it(self):
        self.crash_win = CrashOnTopWindow(self)
        self.crash_win.show()

app = QtWidgets.QApplication()
win = TestMainWindow()
win.show()
app.exec_()
```

Would be nice to see it fixed!

@feaneron No problem, I know there are many things that all you do. I just want to go forward whereas stay in a discussion.

3) Is it per device or well defined ? I don't know but you may find answers in mutter's "bug" (https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=775755) and gsettings-desktop-schemas's "bug" (https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=775756) which have been merged for this option.

b) Tag to Drag NO

c) Drag with Tap ? (I like this)

d) Start Dragging with Tap ?

e) Other ideas ?

events.target_title: add tap-and-drag option

note.body:
I know what it does. There are two ways to drag an object with a touchpad :

· Either you *hold the physical click button of touchpad* to select an object and then you move it with *another* finger by touching the touchpad.

· Either you *tap in touchpad* to select an object and then you move it with *the same* finger by touching the touchpad.

Tap-and-Drag is an option in libinput (library for touchpad) to enable/disable the second way to do.

"Tap and Drag" is to be compared to something like "Click and Drag".

events.target_title: add tap-and-drag option

note.body: @aday Do you have an argument about putting it in Accessibility ?

events.target_title: add tap-and-drag option

note.body:
Hello everybody.

About 2 years after working on this feature (december 2016), some people don't understand what it is yet and so, they block the project.

I encourage people to disable this feature manually by dconf (go to org/gnome/desktop/peripherals/touchpad/tap-and-drag or org.gnome.desktop.peripherals.touchpad tap-and-drag false) to see by themselves what it change. It's a very specific option that is made to be tested and used, not to be understand and explained.

After that, if they still don't understand, it should be very nice that they don't continue to interfere in this project.

To be clear, if you really want to have this option to be disabled, I recommend to people to use dconf whereas waiting another 2 years to use it in gnome-control-center. Sorry for newbies in linux.

I have been looking for usable work around for this for such a long time. It would be so nice to have this working out of the box.
My use case: I have sets of documents in different partitions; home itself is not encrypted. Y keep /home in a fast name drive and documents in other slower drives.

I found the mount --bind  method elsewhere, it doesnt fit my usecase (it doesnt handle encryption well, I nearly made my workstation unusable while testing it)

Looking forward to a simple gnome-like solution: )


Current workaround (it's pretty sad): using catfish (the xfce desktop search tool) since gnome-search-tool no longer exists in distros (unmantained?), with a gnome-shell global shortcut

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
I have been using desktop files for many years in my home folder, with a similar use case as @nemec - my .desktop files are customized to launch various commands with lots of parameters, and in some cases single-line mini-scripts ( bash -c 'do this; do that'), e.g. launch darktable within an OpenCL environment, or launch a backup application within a terminal with specific parameters etc. 

I guess this can easily be replaced with actual one-line scripts in the same folder, but I think I will lose a) the custom icons, b) the ability to easily tweak the parameters using the GUI, c) launch with one click with no prompt to edit (these are scripts I trust; for other scripts, I'd rather get the prompt). Others?

I read here: https://www.omgubuntu.co.uk/2018/05/nautilus-remove-ability-launch-binaries-apps   that double clicking on a script file will also stop working with the next nautilus release (i.e. no script execution any more)?  if so then replacing the desktop files with scripts would not do. Any idea of what could be done to cover the use case?

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
@antoniof sorry I landed here from: https://csorianognome.wordpress.com/2018/07/27/nautilus-3-30/
I thought this was to discuss this,

>  The .desktop files are now treated as normal files: their real file name is shown and they open as text files in applications like GEdit. We leave their graphical edition to more featureful tools like Alacarte. We can provide replacements for some of their uses (you can provide use cases in the ticket). This goes with the vision of having a canonical path for trusting binaries and permissions rather than rely on Nautilus for such a delicate action.

Question - will we be able to create links to .desktop files (stored in ~/.local/share/applications) and expect that nautilus will launch the apps when double clicking those symlinks? That way this migration would be about just moving the desktop files to the proper folder and creating a few symlinks

events.target_title: Introduce suspend-then-hibernate as an option for Power Button  and Lid actions (power saving alternative to suspend)
cannot be configured to not hibernate if hardware supports it

note.body:
Just submitted a feature request to have support for suspend-then-hibernate as actions for Power button & Lid closing, without knowing it was already coming in 3.30.

I agree it would be best to provide UI to allow users to opt out of delayed hibernation. I noticed though that in windows, suspend-then-hibernate became the default way of suspending. It minimizes the chance of losing work and fully discharging the battery - while still providing a very fast resume if only interrupting work for short period of time.

FWIW I use hibernation daily in both desktop and laptop w/gnome. For years. I can't recall the last time I had a problem with it, it's been very stable in my case. 

Currently I'm using suspend-then-hibernate via custom shortcuts

events.target_title: cannot be configured to not hibernate if hardware supports it

note.body:
@smcv another workaround that should work is to extend the timeout to hibernate from the default to a very long time. Assuming gnome is invoking systemctl suspend-then-hibernate and letting it use its configured parameters, you can try setting the timeout to one month or one year.
This is set int /etc/systemd/sleep.conf

[Sleep]
HibernateDelaySec=14400000

events.target_title: Ability to search in Nautilus and sort the results by column

note.body:
I can think of the following two cases:

* You search a term, which may be in the full text, and you happen to remember that the file name started with an A, so you may want to order them alphabetically to get it on top. Even if it started with a G or any other letter, this would be useful because you could search faster the possible results.

* You search a term, which is maybe in the full text, and you happen to remember the approximate size of the file, but nothing about the name. Then sorting by size would be useful to narrow the possibilities.

In general, I think there would be possible use cases for each possible sorting criterion, i.e. for each possible visible column. It would be a pleasure to have this feature available at least for the most common columns.

events.target_title: Crop function crashes gimp 2.10 Windows 10 Pro 64 bit.
Pasted png images from external applications lose alpha information

note.body:
@mitch : I wrote a small Tool that tries to grab everything it can find in the clipboard and dumps it into files. 
Attached is the tool source and two test cases and their respective dumps. 
1. case: A 32bit RGBA bmp, opened in and copied from Windows Photos, Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox.
2. case: A png with auto format, opened in and copied from the same applications.

The file names of the dump have the following pattern: formatid-formatname.dmp. A table of format ids can be found [here](https://msdn.microsoft.com/de-de/library/windows/desktop/ff729168(v=vs.85).aspx) (unfortunately, the names in my dump don't really fit the ids from the table - the ids seem to be correct though). Files with id 8 and 17 contain bitmap information. 

[Clipboard_Dump.zip](/uploads/d9c5bf32f8620cef7c98036bf9776a82/Clipboard_Dump.zip)

events.target_title: Pasted png images from external applications lose alpha information

note.body:
What's interesting is that the dumps with ids 8 and 17 (So the bmps with DIB/DIBv5 header) still seem to include the values from the alpha channel. They have blocks of `868686FF` and `00000000` as you would expect from the given image (also included in the package that I attached in my previous comment). 

I also managed to load the Chrome dump in GIMP with transparency:

1. I added a standard bmp header  `424D 007E 9096 0000 0000 9600 0000` to the front of the dump file.
2. I switched the `00` byte at offset 0x45 (right in front of the `BGRs` string to `FF` because that's how it looked like in the bmp I created with GIMP.

So it looks like Chrome does not set the DIB header correctly when copying the file to the clipboard.

```
export GI_TYPELIB_PATH=/usr/lib64/mutter-5/
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/lib64/mutter-5/
start gjs:

gjs> imports.gi.versions.Clutter = '5'
"5"
gjs> const { Clutter } = imports.gi;
```

=> crash

events.target_title: Events created in month or year view are created with incorrect time and missing timezone

note.body: Now, with Calendar 3.26, it's gotten worse. Now all events created by clicking on a calendar square are displayed at the wrong time in GNOME Shell. But if I create events using the Add Event menu item (that I only just now realized exists), the timezone gets set properly.

events.target_title: event: Fix a minor leak
Events created in month or year view are created with incorrect time and missing timezone

note.body:
And if you hover over any event, the tooltip will list the event timestamp at a *different* and seemingly-arbitrary offset.

For example, when I create an event that begins at 8:30 AM in month view:

 * Calendar (month view) displays the start time at 8:30 AM
 * GNOME Shell displays the start time as 2:30 PM
 * Hovering over the event in Calendar's month view, it displays a tooltip that shows the start time as 1:30 AM. Seems to be always offset by 7. Absolutely no clue why.

This is all 100% reproducible for me (UTC -6:00).

events.target_title: Events created in month or year view are created with incorrect time and missing timezone

note.body:
Still debugging....

>  GNOME Calendar is able to read floating events, but not create them. All events are created with a timezone associated. Calendar uses Evolution-Data-Server to detect the current timezone, and GLib's GDateTime API to handle timezone changes.

That's actually not true. Calendar 3.26.2 *always* creates floating events (i.e. it *never* saves the timezone in the event) if the event is created when in month view or year view. The timezone only gets saved if the event is created in week view or using the Add Event menu item.

Extra words in sentence in help page
Extra words in sentence in help page
Help strings that contains its:translate="no" used for translation
Help strings that contains its:translate="no" used for translation

note.body: Reproduced locally and found the cause. Seeing that the translate:its namespace was recently changed to https in the affected files in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evolution/commit/3fd383376f079fdb5c377d27f1fafe5d26a40021 got me curious regarding whether that could be the cause. Thus I tested with itstool to create a pot file: `$ itstool -o out.pot index.page` One of the entries in this file: `#. (itstool) path: page/title #: index.page:23 msgid " Evolution logo Evolution Mail and Calendar" msgstr ""` Now if I change "https://www.w3.org/2005/11/its" in index.page to instead be "http://www.w3.org/2005/11/its" the same string is now parsed correctly by itstool: `#. (itstool) path: page/title #: index.page:23 msgid "<_:media-1/> Evolution Mail and Calendar" msgstr ""`

events.target_title: Promote patreon work for Timm Bäder's patreon

note.body:
Text as follows - rev 0:  feel free to edit.

The GNOME Foundation is promoting Timm Bäder's patreon as part of an overall push to improve the GTK+ toolkit.  Timm is not only known for his application - corebird, a GTK+ based twitter client, but his substantial work on GTK+ itself.

Well respected by GTK+ developers, Timm has commited over 865 changes to the GTK+ codebase in a ten month timeframe far out pacing any other GTK+ developers this year.

Timm's contributions encompasses work in profiling, widget cleanup, and various others.  Timm has also drove many changes like enabling any widget to have child widgets, and converting all of the gtk3-era gadgets into widgets.

Your contributions will enable Timm to continue this important work in  GTK+ in which so many projects depend on.

events.target_title: Promote pippin's patreon work on GEGL

note.body:
Rev0:

Long-time [GIMP](https://www.gimp.org) developer, Oyvind Kolas (aka pippin), has launched
[a Patreon campaign](https://www.patreon.com/pippin) to fund his ongoing work on [GEGL](https://www.gegl.org/index.html), GIMP's next
generation image processing engine.

GEGL is a image processing engine which can apply complex image manipulation operations with high performance in a non-destructive manner.  What this means is that you can make modifications to an image and it would not affect the original image.  GEGL lends itself to creating high performance operations on images in a manner that can easily allow such operations to be removed as needed.

Oyvind a former Clutter developer, picked up GEGL in the
mid-2000s and has been maintaining it ever since. He has authored 45%
of all commits to GEGL, and thanks to his work GIMP 2.10 will have a wealth of features that artists will be able to take advantage of - bringing us ever closer to greater technical equivalence to commercial photo editors.


We encourage you to support Oyvind via [his Patreon page](https://www.patreon.com/pippin). Sufficient funding will accelerate further enhancements like
non-destructive editing in GIMP, support active maintenance of GEGL,
and allow him to sustain himself while doing so.

Usability Improvement - Option to Pre-Render Image Thumbnails

note.body:
I do the bulk of Photo Work in Shotwell like tagging the 60,000 photos, however I also have to use Nautilus because the directory structure is helpful to identify photos by event and filename -- something simply not possible in shotwell especially if timestamp data is incorrect (then photos are out of order when tagging).

I use Nautilus to view hundreds of Krita Art Files, Photoshop Designs, Photos, PNG's etc... by thumbnail which I then launch Krita, Photoshop, Pixeluvo, etc... as many apps are not designed to navigate "Directories".

The situation gets worse in that some versions of GTK Chooser don't even show a picture so the Apps leave some users even more helpless at locating photos. (Mom, Grandma, etc...)

I mean, I don't expect Nautilus to add in Photo features like Tagging (Which I would love if it did) but I think locating files by thumbnail is really important which is why I believe pre-rendering directory contents as a preferences checkbox would add polish.

With the new experimental thumbnail view, it's so close to perfect for every day use in the work and home environment.
