events.target_title: Remove desktop support

note.body:
As a Gnome user Nautilus Desktop has been a source of frustration for me for 10 years.

Seperating the Binaries was a step in the right direction, and I have personally tried to hack in horizontal layout with some success.

I would like to see Nautilus Desktop decoupled and become a Gnome Shell Extension.

I imagine all of the Enterprise and Corporate interests deem the traditional desktop a requirement.

As a extension, it sounds like it would be easier to mod and extend as the scope of the code would be simplified.

I would like to suggest:

1. Horizontal or Vertical Alignment option

2. Snap to grid layout (Each Icon occupies a 1x1 square

3. Move existing icons out of the way on drag & drop

For me, and anyone who has ADHD from inhuman coffee consumption -- having your icons in your face all the time can be extreemly critical to productivity as you are constantly reminded of what task you are working on since it is right there in front of you.

I would be happy to take a poke at the Extension once the core is prototyped.

events.target_title: Remove desktop support

note.body:
I think the proof of concept extension by @csoriano simplifies the hairy mess that the desktop is into a module which other developers will likely mod into various Desktop Spinoffs.

https://gitlab.gnome.org/csoriano/org.gnome.desktop-icons

It's much easier to work in a 10 file project than a 10,000 file project. I think it's very exciting.

I would be interested in seeing a desktop that is a "Current Working Directory" so my desktop could move from / to ~/Apps/ etc... If I can't help out with the extension now I'll try to mod that in later.

If anyone is interested in trying it out you can use devilspie2 to set thunar to fullscreen, undecorated, transparent and pinned to bottom.

events.target_title: ".hidden" doesn't work for GVFS locations

note.body:
Nautilus 3.26.2, GLib/GIO 2.54.2.

That key is set to false.

Hidden attribute isn't being returned for the SFTP location:

```
$ touch test
$ echo test > .hidden
$ gio info -a standard::is-hidden test
hidden
uri: file:///home/username/test
attributes:
  standard::is-hidden: TRUE
$ ssh remote-host touch test
$ ssh remote-host 'echo test > .hidden'
$ gio info -a standard::is-hidden 'sftp://username@remote-host/home/username/test'
uri: sftp://username@remote-host/home/username/test
attributes:
$
```

Edit: accidentally removed the content of the gio output for the remote file.

events.target_title: ".hidden" doesn't work for GVFS locations

note.body:
>  Not all GVfs backends provide access to unix-based filesystems and thus these conventions

Is a `.hidden` file (a file with that specific name containing a list of files to hide, not a dot file generally) a UNIX convention? Isn't it a more-or-less Nautilus-specific thing?

>  and would just cause additional slowdown

Presumably this could just be handled on the client side (which would probably make more sense since honouring a `.hidden` file is client-specific, assuming there are other GIO clients). Stat-ing (then reading) a single text file shouldn't affect performance much.

For now, anything that would have been a system dependency is managed by the `data/multistrap.conf.in` file in [this repository](https://gitlab.com/BuildStream/debootstrap-ostree/)

I'm not sure if telepathy-idle should be brought in as a sysdep or if it should be built in the GNOME build... should investigate with other release team members.

For testing, we should be sharing the user's session bus automatically in `bst shell` where the sandbox is not isolated by default (there is no protection in the testing shell, only in the build shell/sandbox do we unshare everything with bubblewrap), it seems we need to improve this on the buildstream side of things, we should [track this here](https://gitlab.com/BuildStream/buildstream/issues/223), my thoughts are that a project.conf should be able to inform buildstream about hacks which should be performed and environment variables which should be *"passed through"* in order to improve the developer shell experience.

This patch otherwise looks fine, but I'd like to get the CI pipelines up (we thought that might happen last week but people got derailed) so we can at least see that changes here do not break builds...

events.target_title: Remove desktop files & binaries handling

note.body:
Desktop files have two uses in nautilus, either as application launchers, or as "shortcuts" (Type=Link). The historic plan was to support both symlinks and shortcuts with the difference in behaviour that shortcuts are cross-uri-type and always expand whereas symlinks don't expand when you click them (i.e. if you click on /home and it is a symlink it goes to /home, not to /mnt/sda3/home).

I don't think supporting desktop file app launchers in nautilus are especially important with the desktop gone, but i still think that shortcuts make sense. However, the story there was never fully fleshed out (for instance, its hard to create shortcuts atm, i belive you have to alt-drag-and-drop or something), so if that goes away i would not cry.

events.target_title: Remove desktop files & binaries handling

note.body:
I'm not sure what you mean by improve. First of all, there is no way a symlink could ever point to e.g. a smb:// uri, that just isn't how it works.

But secondly, the two have different usecases. Symlinks are often used by sysadmins to hide lowlevel implementation details of the filesystem and expose a "nice" front to the user. For instance /home could be a symlink to /mnt/largedisk/homedirs. In that case it would be a disservice to users to expand it if you click on it. 

Whereas shortcuts would be something that user would more often create themselves, as a way to quickly go somewhere.

But, i guess if you want to do that these days you use the bookmarks instead, so maybe that isn't really a useful feature anymore...

events.target_title: Cloud providers file in datadir is not flatpak compatible

note.body:
I don't think we want to be adding all kinds of types of export files to flatpak, for several reasons. First of all, you'd need to update the flatpak on the host to get the new feature, but also we'd have to know the details of the formats of all these external format, including how to rewrite them to be safe.

I think using the existing things like desktop files and dbus service files is a much better idea. And having a desktop file doesn't necessarily mean you have to have a UI. You can set NoDisplay=true to avoid it being shown in the menus, etc.

events.target_title: Cloud providers file in datadir is not flatpak compatible

note.body:
Its not worth redoing now, but If you expect things to be extensible like this with a flatpak, yes. 

Otoh, honestly i'm not sure shell providers in flatpaks was the greatest idea.

events.target_title: Network discovery doesn’t work

note.body:
So, this is not a problem with GNOME infrastructure, but anyway I will try to give you some tips...

It seems like a problem with resolving the host, though interesting it is that printer is listed. I am not SAMBA expert, but you can try to disable firewall (or allow necessary ports). Not sure how you can do it on Debian, but `firewall-cmd --add-service=samba --permanent` works nicely on Fedora. You can also try to start nmbd if it is not running already, `service nmbd start`. Also be sure that `browsable = yes` is in your smb.conf.

events.target_title: Can't mount ZFS zpool

note.body:
I don't have many experiences with ZFS, but as far as I can tell it should not be shown in the sidebar, because "zfs" is part of the list of ignored filesystems in GLib (but maybe "zfs_member" should be there also, don't know...):
https://git.gnome.org/browse/glib/commit/?id=4cafadc

The main problem is that it is not yet supported by UDisks due to licensing issues (which is the reason you can see the error):
https://github.com/storaged-project/udisks/issues/42

And a patch to ignore zfs_member partitions has been pushed recently (so they should not be shown in UI as a consequence):
https://github.com/storaged-project/udisks/pull/376

So, closing as a duplicate of those UDisks' bugs.

Celebrating newcomers contributions via social media
Celebrating newcomers contributions via social media

note.body:
@nuritzi Thanks for updating the description. Looks perfect now.

@nuritzi I looked around what you are asking for, something like "Global" labels. However, I did not find any paths in the GitLab user interface to achieve that. So, I am not sure if it is possible yet or not. But I would like to inform you that many people are rooting for that exact feature [0]

However, I discovered another way which might work out for this particular task. *Assuming* that, there is a real person who has to responsibility to send out newcomers contributions tweet, he/she can subscribe to a label [1]

So, the way it works out is that once all newcomers projects are migrated to gitlab, the maintainer will assign the label to the particular issue. This requires that every newcomers(or any) project that wish to tweet out, simply has to make a label regarding it and ping the engagement person to subscribe to that label.

From then on, when the maintainer assigns that particular label(for e.g. "Social media") to an issue( which is fixed), the engagement person will be pinged (as he/she is subscribed to that label). So, this is how I see to work out with minimal effort.

Although I will wait and see if @csoriano has something to say about this or make it better.

[0] https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/2651

[1] https://docs.gitlab.com/ce/user/project/labels.html#subscribe-to-labels

events.target_title: USB Mass Storage shows filesystem as msdos when it is vfat

note.body:
> It seems fs type comes directly from GIO:
> https://git.gnome.org/browse/glib/tree/gio/glocalfile.c?#n653

Yup, and it’s an internal identifier which shouldn’t be shown in the UI. Nautilus should be converting that identifier (or some other `GFile` attribute) to a human-readable, translatable string, and showing that instead.

udisks has code for that: https://github.com/storaged-project/udisks/blob/master/udisks/udisksclient.c#L1948

I’d be happy to add more `GFile` attributes to GLib to expose more information about the file system, if you need them.

events.target_title: Filesystem places and sidebar needs modernisation

note.body: Please allow me, as a layman, to express my humble opinion: On the one side is the system's predefined directory structure is used by all applications, and on the other side is the user's custom requirements are adapted to his or her special working environment. this is a question about different tastes. There is no silver bullet. Why can't we build a bridge to connect the needs of both sides？ like a setting option in the preference window, the user select pre-defined "Projects", then nautilus pop a choose file(folder) dialog, the user can choose folder "project" also he can use his "work" folder instead,  or  just use "$HOME/jhbuild/checkout/" by default.

events.target_title: Month view is hard to read

note.body:
As per today's IRC discussion, I posit the issue with colors parsing is the thickness (you can't easily distinguish dark colors when on a small block instead of a big background block, and adding a thin line across the whole width wouldn't solve the issue). So for this specific usability issue, here's a potential solution (which also happens to be a design compromise between all the opinions I've heard so far):

![git_master_as_of_2017-11-28_-_GIMPed](/uploads/75d270c1bdaf7e761d8213ec6098b871/git_master_as_of_2017-11-28_-_GIMPed.png)

This depends on the timestamp being on the left (for better or for worse); it wouldn't work if they're on the right because the beginning of the label (the event name) wouldn't provide a predictable/coherent width for the solid background color.

Bluesound devices support
Bluesound devices support

note.body:
> What is this thing?

It is a music amplifier with remote control and music library capabilities (for instance, it is able to index music in a NFS mount in a NAS somewhere on your local network), but it needs a remote application to control it.

> Why Lollypop should control an external player?

With #1757 and #1742 it is suggested that Lollypop could play music from remote music sharing services. My suggestion is to also make Lollypop a controller for remote music players. I understand that it is quite a big thing, that it would probably have large design consequences, and would increase the size of the codebase. So I would understand if it is something you do not want Lollypop to do.

> Would have make sense if this device supports DLNA.

I understand from [this comment](https://support1.bluesound.com/hc/en-us/community/posts/203090833/comments/115005320767) from the Bluesound community board that DLNA support is not planned.

If you want Lollypop to act as a DLNA Digital Media Controller (do you?), then controlling Bluesound devices would not be a very different feature. It would just be about using a different API.

> So I tinks the smart way to implement this is to create an MPRIS python service sending MPRIS commands... You can look at mpris.py from Lollypop to create such software.

Your suggestion is to create a daemon that would interface MPRIS to the Bluesound API, and to control my device with an existing MPRIS client? After having a look at the [specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/mpris-spec/2.2/), it seems MPRIS handles playback controls and playlists, but I did not see anything about music libraries.

note.body:
Example desktop file that works:

```desktop
[Desktop Entry]
Comment=
Terminal=false

Exec=/bin/sh -c '$(env PATH="/usr/libexec:/usr/lib/gnome-terminal:$PATH" which gnome-terminal-server) --app-id=fr.mildred.irssi --class=fr.mildred.irssi --name=fr.mildred.irssi & sleep 0.25; gnome-terminal --app-id=fr.mildred.irssi --hide-menubar -e "flatpak run fr.mildred.irssi" '

Version=1.0
```

events.target_title: Integrate terminal applications with Terminal=true in their desktop entry file
Integrate terminal applications with Terminal=true in their desktop entry file

note.body:
Look for the `G_KEY_FILE_DESKTOP_KEY_TERMINAL` key which is handled in `gio/gdesktopappinfo.c`. App launching is implemented in `g_desktop_app_info_launch_uris_with_spawn`, and in particular around `prepend_terminal_to_vector`

Probably, gnome-terminal should add a command-line flags where an app-id and a WMClass are specified, and gnome-terminal should in turn start the gnome-terminal-server with the correct settings. Then gio will just have to use those special command-line flags from gnome-terminal.

What is nice is that gio can also implement this for other terminals it recognizes as many of them directly has a `--class` CLI option.

There is something else: what if the desktop file entry doesn't have a `StartupWMClass` key? Should we disable the feature, or should we generate a StartupWMClass at the risk of not being recognized by the desktop environment for example? What makes the desktop environment associate a window with a desktop entry if there is no WMClass specified?

events.target_title: Integrate terminal applications with Terminal=true in their desktop entry file

note.body: There is one question to answer at the shell level though. in case of desktop entries that don't specify a StartupWMClass, what makes the shell recognize that a window is associated with a particular desktop entry?

events.target_title: Allow to create specific terminal applications (replace deprecated --class CLI option)

note.body:
See also https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/issues/1584

Probably, it would be nice if gnome-terminal had a command line flag that could specify an alternate app-id, and in that case gnome-terminal would start a gnome-terminal-server with the corresponding app-id and WM class.

This way, when confronted with a desktop entry with `Terminal=true`, glib gio could just start gnome-terminal with those specific flags, and wouldn't have to deal with starting gnome-terminal-server which may not remain stable in the long term.

Or perhaps this doesn't belongs to gnome-terminal but to a wrapper that would do both.

events.target_title: Allow to create specific terminal applications (replace deprecated --class CLI option)
Allow to create specific terminal applications (replace deprecated --class CLI option)

note.body:
However, when I specify an app-id that doesn't correspond to any g-t-s, it errors out with `Error creating terminal: The name local.foo was not provided by any .service files` without falling back to the default server. It happens in `handle_options` right after the call to `terminal_factory_call_create_instance_sync` failed.

`terminal_factory_call_create_instance_sync` seems to be a dBus call (automatically generated by dBus bindings). So it fails because the terminal server is not present.

At this point, we should detect the error, start g-t-s and retry.

events.target_title: Allow to create specific terminal applications (replace deprecated --class CLI option)

note.body:
More specifically, in `main()` we create the factory here:

```c
  if (!factory_proxy_new (options,
                          &factory,
                          &service_name,
                          &parent_screen_object_path,
                          &error))
    return exit_code;
```

At this point, we should check if it works (if there is a g-t-s at the other end) and if not, launch g-t-s. Or perhaps decide that based on a CLI flag such as `--start-server` so we don't check for the server each time gnome-terminal starts.

events.target_title: [Wayland] gtk_window_present() not working

note.body:
Another valid use case:

- User defines a custom hot key in gnome-control-center to launch an application

On keypress gnome-shell spawns the application (and while it could in theory pass the event timestamp via an environment variable or something, currently it doesn't), the application talks to an already-running copy via dbus (via GApplication APIs), and the already-running copy wants to bring its window to front.

(As a workaround today I hide and show the application's window, which reliably brings it to front -- focus stealing?  ha, there's your focus stealing -- but forgets its position on screen.)

events.target_title: Vino seems to be incompatible with all Android VNC clients
Obey tracker ignored files/directories in simple search engine

note.body:
The patch looks good, and will probably help in consistency with the tracker search engine. One nit I find is that nautilus doesn't directly depend on tracker-miners, so the existence of the gschema is not guaranteed.

I think the patch should probably either add an explicit pkg-config dependency on tracker-miners, or look up the schema through g_settings_schema_source_lookup() before poking non-existing settings.

In reply to @antoniof:
> Tracker's ignore-files list is about not indexing, rather than not searching.

Well, in Tracker both are mixed :), if it's not indexed, it will "not exist" when searching.

> 
> Why should we not let nautilus search for non-indexed files?
> 
> In particular, tracker files miner does not index *.desktop files, but I don't see why nautilus simple search engine shouldn't find them.
> 
> '*~', '*.o', '*.la', '*.lo' , '*.loT', '*.in', '*.csproj', '*.m4', '*.rej', '*.gmo', '*.orig', '*.pc', '*.omf', '*.aux', '*.tmp', '*.po', '*.vmdk', '*.vm*', '*.nvram', '*.part', '*.rcore', '*.lzo', 'autom4te', 'conftest', 'confstat', 'Makefile', 'SCCS', 'ltmain.sh', 'libtool', 'config.status', 'confdefs.h', 'configure', '#*#', '~$*.doc?', '~$*.dot?', '~$*.xls?', '~$*.xlt?', '~$*.xlam', '~$*.ppt?', '~$*.pot?', '~$*.ppam', '~$*.ppsm', '~$*.ppsx', '~$*.vsd?', '~$*.vss?', '~$*.vst?', '*.desktop', '*.directory'

That's an historic artifact in Tracker, as you can see the filter is mostly populated of auxiliary/temporary/generated files. Desktop files are legit to have spread around the filesystem and fit in neither category. Feel free to file a bug to Tracker to have it actually handle those.

events.target_title: Moving Starred file leaves "ghost" file in favorites:///

note.body:
I think the handling of deleted events at on_tracker_notifier_events() in nautilus-tag-manager.c isn't right.

As per https://developer.gnome.org/libtracker-sparql/unstable/TrackerNotifier.html , code will always get location_uri=NULL on delete events. Later on, nautilus_tag_manager_file_with_id_changed_url() is able to cope with the given NULL URI and return the previous location for the file, which is then replaced in the favorite_files hashtable with an entry that has a NULL key, thus the "ghost" file.

I think the if (new_location_uri)... path in that function should handle location_uri=NULL and avoid everything but the g_hash_table_remove(), although the query happening on that file later on also seems superfluous.

Positioning layers regressed from 2.42.6 and 2.43.4
Positioning layers regressed from 2.42.6 and 2.43.4

note.body:
It is probably easiest to show with an example. See here how the rendering is different between the two versions. The line defined in its own layer is no longer in the correct position.

events.target_title: .desktop file fails with unhelpful error message "The was an error launching the application"

note.body: An error message needs to contain the reason for the failure. There is no downside in including it no matter how useful the message is for the recipient. It _can_ include further instructions how to fix the error or that it'd be nice to report it to the developers, but it's hard to implement and manage and not important in comparison. The only important thing in this world is: Never give an error message without a reason! Never!

events.target_title: .desktop file fails with unhelpful error message "The was an error launching the application"

note.body: @antoniof Imo you can't avoid to be too technical in this case because it's a very technical issue. I think "say(ing) that the binary pointed by the "Exec=" key was not found" is sufficient. Opening the file in a text editor is an option, depending on user experience (that comes back to the first point), which doesn't influence the error message.

Please, incorporate the following patch to your branch:

https://paste.gnome.org/pw7zspgmn

`git am < filename.patch`

events.target_title: Recurring (repetitive) tasks feature

note.body:
I really liked the Android app "Habits" https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=org.isoron.uhabits (no spam intended, just good usage design example). The design is nice, but we could make it wayy simpler. For each task you can set a custom interval. For example wash the dishes every 2 days.

The "Task" entity needs to have a "latest done date" programmatical field, if the difference of date between today and the latest done date is higher or equals the interval, make it appear in the list as "to do". This way, the user doesn't feel forced to wash the dishes, but he knows that he needs to. As simple as that.

When the user check the done box, it sets the "original done date" to "latest done date" and "latest done date" to today's date; disappearing from the todo list until today's date plus interval. If he uncheck it, "latest done date" becomes "original done date"; 

Would need 2 checkboxes in the burger menu to show/hide : archived, done.

Some sorting feature to sort by : 
- number of days since last done minus interval of days (procrastinated stuff first)
- interval of days (rare stuff first)

Very simple and efficient design. AAANNNNDDDDDDDDDD Help to gain good habits.

I would be absolutely honored to implement it if this design seems good to you. I am waiting for your signal to start the work !

## Usage example

Some dude wakes up sunday morning. What I am gonna do in this sunday morning my dude ? He says to his dog. He open his Gnome ToDo app and what he sees :

- Paint the fence (every 1 year)
- Cook food for the week (each 1 week)
- Wash the clothes (each 3 days)
- Go run outside (everyday)
- Play with dog (everyday)
- .. more stuff

This way the ToDo app almost become some kind of life Quest Log for cyberaddicts individuals.
